Baltimore, Md., February 7, 1910.

Price, 5 cents per copy.

To the A lumni of the Johns Hopkins University
The strength of a university does
not lie entirely in the size of its faculty, the number of its students, or
the length of its curriculum. It lies
equally in the enthusiasm and loyalty
of those, who in any capacity, from
president and trustees to newly matriculated students, are concerned in
its welfare. Of this academic community the alumnus is integrally a
part. He has received a degree, either
as bachelor, master, or doctor,
Which makes him one of a great corporate body and he does not cease to
be a member even though he have
long since ceased to be actively connected with the affairs of the institution. Upon the faculty rests a heavy
responsibility of hearty and self-sacrificing interest in maintaining the
standards of the university and in
sharing in the common effort to keep
the pace that is necessary in the face
of the tremendous competition that
Prevails today in American academic circles. No university can live
that is atrophied in any of its parts
and in which those entrusted with the
gnardianships of its reputation or influence are careless of or neglectful of
their trust. That which is true of the
faculty is also true of the alumni. No
institution can reach or maintain a
high degree of efficiency or influence
Whose alumni have separated themselves from it in sympathy as well as
In body, and have ceased to have organic connection with the corporate
organization to which they legally belong.
No factor is more conspicuous in
the history of our colleges and universities of the present day than the
Part which the alumni are taking in
returning to their alma mater some
measure of that gratitude which they
owe for the help they have received
from her in the development of their
characters and careers. This debt is
too often forgotten in the pressure of
Other duties and occupations, because
It Is a matter not of business, but of
sentiment, a debt which cannot be
collected by process of law. There
are few finer things in the world than
the expression of loyalty and few
that are more disheartening than
apathy and indifference wherever
they may be found. A university that
cannot command the best services of
:ts men and has lost the devotion of
Its alumni is likely to become immobile, and immobility is dangerously
near stagnation.
The living alumni of the Johns
Ronkins University are now more
than twenty-one hundred in number.
They are •made up of three groups:

The doctors of philosophy, the doctors of medicine, and the bachelors of
arts with a few proficients in electricity. There are nearly 750 living
doctors of philosophy, nearly 600 living doctors of medicine, over 700 living bachelors of arts who are neither
Ph. D's nor M. D's, and 90 proficients in electricity. The bachelors of
arts are in the main living within the
smallest geographical circle, a large
number being residents of Maryland
and the city of Baltimore; the doctors of medicine are more widely
scattered, though the great majority
are practicing their profession east
of the Mississippi River; the doctors of philosophy are spreadall over
the country from Canada to Texas
and from Maine to California.
Hitherto, by virtue of their nearness to the University and because of
the compactness of their interests
the bachelors of arts have been most
prominently representative of the
alumni as a wh6le. They have organized the Alumni Association and
have given it something of the character of a Baltimore club; they have
been interested more closely than others in the collegiate life of the university, particularly on the athletic
side; and they have been able to aid
the university by personal influence
and financial means, partly because
so many are residents of the city
where the university is located and
partly because as engaged in the
more paying professions or in business they have had the opportunity
and the means wherewith to act.
Next in the scale of intimate connection with the university stand the
doctors of medicine, a remarkably
progressive and enlightened body of
men. Their loyalty, which has been
able to show itself less perhaps in material forms than in expressions of
attachment, has been due in no small
measure to the personality of those
who constitute the medical faculty
and to the esprit de corps which to
every observer is manifest among
those. faculty, lecturers, students and
alumni, who make up the medical
school. Amon rf the M. D's thfclasses have been larger and the
years since graduation fewer than is
the case with the doctors on the philosophical side.
Lowest in the scale of attachment
stand these same doctors of philosophy. More distant from the university in time and space, finding their
lot cast generally in other institutions of learning—universities, colres and schools—they have inevitle,

ably formed new academic associations and have allowed their new environment to dull their interest in the
university which gave them their degrees. Equally potent perhaps has
been the absence of any organized attempt on the part of the university
itself or of the Alumni Association to
bring them into a closer union or to
demonstrate by systematic appeals the
need of their cooperation. Behind all
else lies the question which has arisen
in the mind of many an old graduate
as to the place of the Johns Hopkins
in the university world. A widely
expressed feeling prevails that the
vitality which characterized the graduate department in its earlier years
is lessening and that the vigor and
freshness which aroused enthusiasm
at the first is breaking with the lapse
of a generation of time. Whether
justified or not this belief has done
much to deaden the interest and sympathy of the graduates on the philosophical side, and where approbation
is wanting loyalty cannot be maintained.
By the vote of nearly a thousand
alumni and with the approval of the
president and board of trustees, there
was erected nearly a year ago an
Alumni Council made up of representatives of all the groups of alumni and from as wide a geographical
area as was consistent with attendance. This council had its first meeting on May 1, 1909, and at that time
apportioned the work to be done
among its members. A second meeting was held in December when reports were presented and discussed.
Among other things the council authorized the establishment of an official alumni organ of communication,
and pending the final decision as to
its character, determined to make an
appeal to the alumni as a whole for
cooperation and support. It believed
and still believes that when once the
attention of the alumni is called to
the situation as it now exists, to the
fact that the Johns Hopkins University is still a great institution neither paralyzed nor moribund, to the new
zeal which is aroused among those
who are near at hand and know the
conditions and have absolute confidence in the future of the University,
they will respond, not necessarily
with money, but with a new sympathy and a willingness to help as far
as each one is able. The Alumni
Council stands for no group or section; it stands for the whole body of
two thousand graduates, and it turns
to them on this occasion asking that

they aid it in its efforts to strengthen
the University.
he appeal is not
in this instance for money wherewith
to complete the fund that the University is trying to raise, but it is for
the little that each man can do to
show his sympathetic interest in what
the council is doing and to further
a course that every one should have
at heart.
The Alumni Council believes that
every alumnus can do one or all of
the following things and that in so
doing he will make possible what the
council has placed before itself as
among the necessary ends to be
sought.
1. Join the Alumni Association
and thus make it the organization of
the alumni as a whole, the funds of
which will be used not in the interest of any one locality or group of
alumni, but for the purposes which
the council wishes to carry out in
behalf of every member wherever
he may be. Were the Alumni Association even approximately coincident
with the entire body of the alumni it
would not only bring into existence
a yearly revenue that would be used
wisely and economically, but it would
also create a unity that would in-crease the loyalty of every man for
his alma mater.
2.
Cooperate in the maintenance
of an alumni journal, which whether
issued monthly or quarterly would
become a medium of communication
between the different parts of the
greater university and would furnish knowledge of the doings of the
University on one side and of the
alumni on the other. Such cooperation can take two forms: a guaranteed subscription for as many years
as possible, that the publication may
be assured of its future; a sending of
articles or items regarding oneself or
others such as will be of interest and
value to all. Scores of events are
happening daily among the alumni
that should be known, both for their
own intrinsic importance and for the
reputation of the University. Knowledge of each of the others is a factor of prime importance in stimulating solidarity among the alumni.
3. Organize local associations or
join those already existing and let
these associations become not only
centers of Hopkins enthusiasm, but
also channels of communication with
the council and with the larger association. There ought to be a chain
of associations throughout the country, each of which will have its
space in the new publication, will

THE NEWS-LETTER,

February 7,

1910.

To the Medical Alumni of the Johns Hopkins University
At the time the Johns Hopkins
Medical School was founded in 1893,
very few friends of the University
believed that it would be possible for
its Medical Department to undergo
such a great development in point of
attendance as has since been experienced. It was almost universal,y expected that this department would remain a small school appealing to that
limited number of college graduates
who were about to enter the medical
profession with the idea of doing
scientific work along medical lines.
The wisdom of requiring an academic
degree before entering upon medical
studies in this newly established
school of medicine was even doubted
by some of the influential friends of
the University, on the ground that
,file„ attendance Would never be large
enough to jutify its foundation.
This department, however, has
grown in a remarkable degree. To
such an extent indeed has the attendance increased that at the present
time the Johns Hopkins has one of
the largest, if not the largest, medical schools in the country if we conicier the schools with rigid requirements fot admission.
Thus far thirteen classes have been
graduated, and the size of the classes
has steadily grown until the present
fourth year—about to graduate in June
—numbers'seventy Men as compared
with the original class of 1897 which
Still larger
included but fifteen.
numbers have been granted medical
degrees, notably in the yeal 1906,
when eighty-five men received their
diplomas.
During the past three years the
number of medical students has markedly increased and the applications
for admission show no signs of falling off. Thus one hundred and eight
applications for the present first
Year class were accepted by the facility and of the men accepted ninetythree are now in attendance. Unless
some unforeseen factors influence the
development of the school, there can
be little doubt that within a period of
five years we shall have between four
and five hundred medical students in

hundred and fifty men have taken the

J. H. U. medical degree, and these
men are engaged in the active practice of their profession or in teaching
positions in nearly every State in the
Union, possibly the larger number
being located in the Eastern Atlantic
States, especially in the cities of Baltimore, Washington, New York, and
Boston. Our graduates have spread
all over the West and South as well
as in many of the more important
cities of New York and New England, such as Buffalo, Albany, New,
Haven, and Hartford, Hopkins medical men hold important posts.
Like her mother University, whose
ideals she has adopted and made her
own, the medical department by
means of its graduates has taken no
small part in the development of
education in other medical schools in
this country, and at the present time
this University is represented in the
medical faculties of nearly all the
more important schools. To indicate how the Hopkins medical graduates have attained special prominence in other universities, one may
mention MacCallum of Columbia,
Hastings and Coe of Cornell, Pratt,
Gay, Christian, and Verhoeff of Harvard, Lyon of Buffalo, Elting, Sampcon, and Winne of Albany, Flint,
Rand. Steele. and Lewis 9f Yale,
Wooley of Cincinnati, Hewett of
Michigan, Schenck of Detroit, Perkins, Ladd. and Marine of Western
Reserve, Meyer of Leland Stanford.
Lynch of Rush Medical School, Kyes
of Chicago, Long-cope of Pennsylvania, Yates and Madison of Milwaukee, Steensland and Waite of
Syracuse, and Dollev of North Carolina. In two medical schools especially is Hopkins University represented, in Wisconsin where Bardeen,
Erlanger, Bunting, and Loevenhardt
hold professorships, and in Virginia
where Marshall. Eyster, and Watts
are the heads of departments.

PROGRAMME FOR THE MEDICAL REUNION
While it is quite too early to give
tie programe in detail or the Medical Reunion on Friday and Saturday,
May 6.th and 7th, it seems advisable
to give a rough draft of what will
inost likely be done on those two
days.
On Friday, the first day, there will
be a general meeting in the morning
at which various addresses will be
illade by members of the faculty, following the formal address of welcome, which will in all probability be
delivered by Dr. Welch.
From twelve to one the medical and
surgical clinics will be given, and
from one to two thirty luncheon will
be served.

During the afternoon there will be
special demonstrations in the various laboratories, the Clinical, Hunterian, Pathological, etc., etc., and in
the later afternoon all will be invited to attend the Clinical, Pathological Conference.
In the evening the classes will meet
separately, and effect their permanent organizations, after which it is
probable that formal class suppers
will be held.
The morning of the second day
will be devoted to rounds in the various wards., Medical and Surgical
clinics, and especial demonstrations
in the various laboratories.

In the afternoon a number of receptions will be given by various
members of the faculty, while in the
evening a banquet will be held.
We feel that the programme will
be *a. most attractive one, and that
those who attend will find both pleasure and profit in their two days visit
to the scenes of their former labors.
We therefore earnestl urge every
graduate of the Johns Hopkins Medical School to bend every effort to
spend these two days in Baltimore,
where old associations can be renewed, and where the bond between
Medical School, Hospital and student
can be rendered even stronger than
it has been in the past.

HONOR SYSTEM
The proposed introduction of the
honor System continues to be one of
the chief themes of conversation
around the University. Since the
Junior Class has taken the matter
up and put forth through its committee a definite plan of action, and
especially since the newspapers of the
city have brought the movement to
the attention of the public, a general
feeling has been evident that the matter must be settled definitely. Either
we must follow the lead of many of
the most prominent colleges by adopting the proposed plan or some modification of it, or else we must reach
a definite decision against it. For
the benefit of all those concerned in
settling the question, faculty and students alike, The News-Letter is anxious to have a general expression of
the views of the alumni regarding
the Honor System at Johns Hopkins.
This is not the first time that the
matter has come up, and the experience of those who wrestled with the
problem before can not but prove
of value at this time. That the alumni
are interested we are very sure; some
letters already published prove that
But we hope that their interest will
lead many others to state their views
through these columns, and that the
lass organizations will wherever possible take some definite action by
Which we may get the benefit of
their opinions. The increasing interest of our graduates in the doings
Of their successors here, of which
this issue of The News-Letter is an
evidence, can nowhere find better employment than in helping in the deci
Sion of the present problem.

HARESFOOT CLUB
A temporary cast for the Haresfoot
production has been chosen and rehearsals have already started. The
main play will be "The Barrister,"
by J. H. Darnley and G. Manville
Fenn. The male characters will probably be taken by Woods, Price, Goddard, McCabe, Buckler, Stollenwerck,
Belt, and Waters. Female parts will
be taken by Donoho, Lee, Frederick,
Cole and Marston. The"curtain raiser," a little farce called "Hearing Is
Believing," will be played by Getz
and Rogers.
Two performances will be given in
the city and negotiations for two
trips—one to Richmcnd and one to
Staunton—are under way. Alumni
especially are urged to support the
performances and to secure boxes
from the business manager for class
reunicns. The play last year was a
"howling success" and this year's
promises to be equally successful.

THE DANCE
The Cotillon Club held its second
dance of the season last Friday even-7
ing. The dance was one of the most
attractive and successful ever held
by the club. The hall was tastefully
decorated with class flags and banners. M.any of this year's and next
year's debutantes were present.
The program consisted of sixteen
dances and several extras. Between
the eighth and ninth dances, supper
was served. The committee that arranged the dance was composed of

AUSPICES OF THE ALUMNI COUNCIL

711=11E NEWS LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 13.

Baltimore, Md., February 7, 1910.

Price, 5 cents per copy.

To the A lumni of the Johns Hopkins University
The strength of a university does
not lie entirely in the size of its faculty, the number of its students, or
the length of its curriculum. It lies
equally in the enthusiasm and loyalty
of those, who in any capacity, from
president and trustees to newly matriculated students, are concerned in
its welfare. Of this academic community the alumnus is integrally a
part. He has received a degree, either
as bachelor, master, or doctor,
Which makes him one of a great corporate body and he does not cease to
be a member even though he have
long since ceased to be actively connected with the affairs of the institution. Upon the faculty rests a heavy
responsibility of hearty and self-sacrificing interest in maintaining the
standards of the university and in
sharing in the common effort to keep
the pace that is necessary in the face
of the tremendous competition that
Prevails today in American academic circles. No university can live
that is atrophied in any of its parts
and in which those entrusted with the
gnardianships of its reputation or influence are careless of or neglectful of
their trust. That which is true of the
faculty is also true of the alumni. No
institution can reach or maintain a
high degree of efficiency or influence
Whose alumni have separated themselves from it in sympathy as well as
In body, and have ceased to have organic connection with the corporate
organization to which they legally belong.
No factor is more conspicuous in
the history of our colleges and universities of the present day than the
Part which the alumni are taking in
returning to their alma mater some
measure of that gratitude which they
owe for the help they have received
from her in the development of their
characters and careers. This debt is
too often forgotten in the pressure of
Other duties and occupations, because
It Is a matter not of business, but of
sentiment, a debt which cannot be
collected by process of law. There
are few finer things in the world than
the expression of loyalty and few
that are more disheartening than
apathy and indifference wherever
they may be found. A university that
cannot command the best services of
:ts men and has lost the devotion of
Its alumni is likely to become immobile, and immobility is dangerously
near stagnation.
The living alumni of the Johns
Ronkins University are now more
than twenty-one hundred in number.
They are •made up of three groups:

The doctors of philosophy, the doctors of medicine, and the bachelors of
arts with a few proficients in electricity. There are nearly 750 living
doctors of philosophy, nearly 600 living doctors of medicine, over 700 living bachelors of arts who are neither
Ph. D's nor M. D's, and 90 proficients in electricity. The bachelors of
arts are in the main living within the
smallest geographical circle, a large
number being residents of Maryland
and the city of Baltimore; the doctors of medicine are more widely
scattered, though the great majority
are practicing their profession east
of the Mississippi River; the doctors of philosophy are spreadall over
the country from Canada to Texas
and from Maine to California.
Hitherto, by virtue of their nearness to the University and because of
the compactness of their interests
the bachelors of arts have been most
prominently representative of the
alumni as a wh6le. They have organized the Alumni Association and
have given it something of the character of a Baltimore club; they have
been interested more closely than others in the collegiate life of the university, particularly on the athletic
side; and they have been able to aid
the university by personal influence
and financial means, partly because
so many are residents of the city
where the university is located and
partly because as engaged in the
more paying professions or in business they have had the opportunity
and the means wherewith to act.
Next in the scale of intimate connection with the university stand the
doctors of medicine, a remarkably
progressive and enlightened body of
men. Their loyalty, which has been
able to show itself less perhaps in material forms than in expressions of
attachment, has been due in no small
measure to the personality of those
who constitute the medical faculty
and to the esprit de corps which to
every observer is manifest among
those. faculty, lecturers, students and
alumni, who make up the medical
school. Amon rf the M. D's thfclasses have been larger and the
years since graduation fewer than is
the case with the doctors on the philosophical side.
Lowest in the scale of attachment
stand these same doctors of philosophy. More distant from the university in time and space, finding their
lot cast generally in other institutions of learning—universities, colres and schools—they have inevitle,

ably formed new academic associations and have allowed their new environment to dull their interest in the
university which gave them their degrees. Equally potent perhaps has
been the absence of any organized attempt on the part of the university
itself or of the Alumni Association to
bring them into a closer union or to
demonstrate by systematic appeals the
need of their cooperation. Behind all
else lies the question which has arisen
in the mind of many an old graduate
as to the place of the Johns Hopkins
in the university world. A widely
expressed feeling prevails that the
vitality which characterized the graduate department in its earlier years
is lessening and that the vigor and
freshness which aroused enthusiasm
at the first is breaking with the lapse
of a generation of time. Whether
justified or not this belief has done
much to deaden the interest and sympathy of the graduates on the philosophical side, and where approbation
is wanting loyalty cannot be maintained.
By the vote of nearly a thousand
alumni and with the approval of the
president and board of trustees, there
was erected nearly a year ago an
Alumni Council made up of representatives of all the groups of alumni and from as wide a geographical
area as was consistent with attendance. This council had its first meeting on May 1, 1909, and at that time
apportioned the work to be done
among its members. A second meeting was held in December when reports were presented and discussed.
Among other things the council authorized the establishment of an official alumni organ of communication,
and pending the final decision as to
its character, determined to make an
appeal to the alumni as a whole for
cooperation and support. It believed
and still believes that when once the
attention of the alumni is called to
the situation as it now exists, to the
fact that the Johns Hopkins University is still a great institution neither paralyzed nor moribund, to the new
zeal which is aroused among those
who are near at hand and know the
conditions and have absolute confidence in the future of the University,
they will respond, not necessarily
with money, but with a new sympathy and a willingness to help as far
as each one is able. The Alumni
Council stands for no group or section; it stands for the whole body of
two thousand graduates, and it turns
to them on this occasion asking that

they aid it in its efforts to strengthen
the University.
he appeal is not
in this instance for money wherewith
to complete the fund that the University is trying to raise, but it is for
the little that each man can do to
show his sympathetic interest in what
the council is doing and to further
a course that every one should have
at heart.
The Alumni Council believes that
every alumnus can do one or all of
the following things and that in so
doing he will make possible what the
council has placed before itself as
among the necessary ends to be
sought.
1. Join the Alumni Association
and thus make it the organization of
the alumni as a whole, the funds of
which will be used not in the interest of any one locality or group of
alumni, but for the purposes which
the council wishes to carry out in
behalf of every member wherever
he may be. Were the Alumni Association even approximately coincident
with the entire body of the alumni it
would not only bring into existence

To the Medical Alumni of the Johns Hopkins University
At the time the Johns Hopkins
Medical School was founded in 1893,
very few friends of the University
believed that it would be possible for
its Medical Department to undergo
such a great development in point of
attendance as has since been experienced. It was almost universal,y expected that this department would remain a small school appealing to that
limited number of college graduates
who were about to enter the medical
profession with the idea of doing
scientific work along medical lines.
The wisdom of requiring an academic
degree before entering upon medical
studies in this newly established
school of medicine was even doubted
by some of the influential friends of
the University, on the ground that
,file„ attendance Would never be large
enough to jutify its foundation.
This department, however, has
grown in a remarkable degree. To
such an extent indeed has the attendance increased that at the present
time the Johns Hopkins has one of
the largest, if not the largest, medical schools in the country if we conicier the schools with rigid requirements fot admission.
Thus far thirteen classes have been
graduated, and the size of the classes
has steadily grown until the present
fourth year—about to graduate in June
—numbers'seventy Men as compared
with the original class of 1897 which
Still larger

numbers have been granted medical
degrees, notably in the yeal 1906,
when eighty-five men received their
diplomas.
During the past three years the
number of medical students has markedly increased and the applications
for admission show no signs of falling off. Thus one hundred and eight
applications for the present first
Year class were accepted by the facility and of the men accepted ninetythree are now in attendance. Unless
some unforeseen factors influence the
development of the school, there can
be little doubt that within a period of
five years we shall have between four

Boston. Our graduates have spread
all over the West and South as well
as in many of the more important
cities of New York and New England, such as Buffalo, Albany, New,
Haven, and Hartford, Hopkins medical men hold important posts.
Like her mother University, whose

PROGRAMME FOR THE MEDICAL REUNION
While it is quite too early to give
tie programe in detail or the Medical Reunion on Friday and Saturday,
May 6.th and 7th, it seems advisable
to give a rough draft of what will
inost likely be done on those two
days.
On Friday, the first day, there will
be a general meeting in the morning
at which various addresses will be
illade by members of the faculty, following the formal address of welcome, which will in all probability be
delivered by Dr. Welch.
From twelve to one the medical and
surgical clinics will be given, and
from one to two thirty luncheon will
be served.

During the afternoon there will be
special demonstrations in the various laboratories, the Clinical, Hunterian, Pathological, etc., etc., and in
the later afternoon all will be invited to attend the Clinical, Pathological Conference.
In the evening the classes will meet
separately, and effect their permanent organizations, after which it is
probable that formal class suppers
will be held.
The morning of the second day
will be devoted to rounds in the various wards., Medical and Surgical
clinics, and especial demonstrations
in the various laboratories.

In the afternoon a number of receptions will be given by various
members of the faculty, while in the
evening a banquet will be held.
We feel that the programme will
be *a. most attractive one, and that
those who attend will find both pleasure and profit in their two days visit
to the scenes of their former labors.
We therefore earnestl urge every
graduate of the Johns Hopkins Medical School to bend every effort to
spend these two days in Baltimore,
where old associations can be renewed, and where the bond between
Medical School, Hospital and student
can be rendered even stronger than
it has been in the past.

HONOR SYSTEM
The proposed introduction of the
honor System continues to be one of
the chief themes of conversation
around the University. Since the
Junior Class has taken the matter
up and put forth through its committee a definite plan of action, and
especially since the newspapers of the
city have brought the movement to
the attention of the public, a general
feeling has been evident that the matter must be settled definitely. Either
we must follow the lead of many of
the most prominent colleges by adopting the proposed plan or some modification of it, or else we must reach
a definite decision against it. For
the benefit of all those concerned in
settling the question, faculty and students alike, The News-Letter is anxious to have a general expression of
the views of the alumni regarding
the Honor System at Johns Hopkins.
This is not the first time that the
matter has come up, and the experience of those who wrestled with the
problem before can not but prove
of value at this time. That the alumni
are interested we are very sure; some
letters already published prove that
But we hope that their interest will
lead many others to state their views
through these columns, and that the
lass organizations will wherever possible take some definite action by
Which we may get the benefit of
their opinions. The increasing interest of our graduates in the doings
Of their successors here, of which
this issue of The News-Letter is an
evidence, can nowhere find better employment than in helping in the deci
Sion of the present problem.

HARESFOOT CLUB
A temporary cast for the Haresfoot
production has been chosen and rehearsals have already started. The
main play will be "The Barrister,"
by J. H. Darnley and G. Manville
Fenn. The male characters will probably be taken by Woods, Price, Goddard, McCabe, Buckler, Stollenwerck,
Belt, and Waters. Female parts will
be taken by Donoho, Lee, Frederick,
Cole and Marston. The"curtain raiser," a little farce called "Hearing Is
Believing," will be played by Getz
and Rogers.
Two performances will be given in
the city and negotiations for two
trips—one to Richmcnd and one to
Staunton—are under way. Alumni
especially are urged to support the
performances and to secure boxes
from the business manager for class
reunicns. The play last year was a
"howling success" and this year's
promises to be equally successful.

In preparation for the opening of
the lacrosse season early in April,
Coach Alan M. Chesney of the black
and blue twelve is keeping his large
squad of candidates hard at work.
The candidates have been practicing regularly three times a week since
the beginning of the year. Many of
them are now quite proficient in
stickwork, and can be relied upon to

THE NEWS-LETTER,February 7, 1910.
THE DANCE
The Cotillon Club held its second
dance of the season last Friday even-7
ing. The dance was one of the most
attractive and successful ever held
by the club. The hall was tastefully
decorated with class flags and banners. M.any of this year's and next
year's debutantes were present.
The program consisted of sixteen
dances and several extras. Between
the eighth and ninth dances, supper
was served. The committee that arranged the dance was composed of
Messrs. Edmund B. Clary(chairman),
E. Carrol Stollenwerck (secretary),
Edward D. Martin, Frederick C. Lee,
Alan C. Woods, and G. Harvey
Haynes.
The chaperons, the wives of the
members of the Faculty, were Mesdames Ira Remsen, R. T. Abercrombie, Joseph S. Ames, C. M. Andrews,
F. • A. Andrews, M. Bloomfield, W.
